title.value: From analytic to synthetic-organizational pluralisms: A pluralistic enactive psychiatry
title.justification: The title is given at the beginning of the article and in the citation section.
title.quote: Gauld C, Nielsen K, Job M, Bottemanne H and Dumas G (2022) From analytic to synthetic-organizational pluralisms: A pluralistic enactive psychiatry. Front. Psychiatry 13:981787. doi: 10.3389/fpsyt.2022.981787

extractions.description: The paper explores the application of pluralistic frameworks in psychiatry and the enactive approach as a response to the integrative needs of the field. It examines how these concepts can aid in understanding mental disorders by incorporating diverse perspectives (cognitive, biological, phenomenological, etc.) and advocates for an integrative, synthetic-organizational approach to psychiatric practice.

type.justification: The paper focuses on theoretical frameworks and philosophical discussions related to psychiatry rather than empirical data or experimentation.
type.quote: In other words, the enactive approach to psychiatry is predominantly theoretical/conceptual in nature.

name.justification: The paper deals with pluralistic frameworks in psychiatry and the enactive approach to psychiatric disorders.
name.quote: In this paper, we consider the relationships between the different kinds of pluralistic frameworks and this enactive approach for psychiatry.

name.justification: Cognitive science is a significant part of the paper's discussion, particularly in relation to the enactive approach.
name.quote: On one side, the enactive framework anchored both in cognitive sciences, theory of dynamic systems, systems biology, and phenomenology, has recently been proposed as an answer to the challenge of an integrative psychiatry.

name.justification: Neuroscience is mentioned as part of the pluralistic approaches discussed in the paper.
name.quote: KEYWORDS: psychiatry, enaction, cognitive science, enaction and embodied cognition, pluralism, neuroscience.

name.justification: The article was submitted to the Social Neuroscience section of the journal, indicating its relevance to this subfield.
name.quote: This article was submitted to Social Neuroscience, a section of the journal Frontiers in Psychiatry.
